Sharon puts a hand to Tish’s forehead, gentle. That same on Tish’s shoulder now:
Tish, I don’t think you got nothing to cry about. (and now) You tell Fonny?
I just told him today. I figured I should tell him first.
You did right. And I bet he just grinned all over his face.
(laughing) Yes. (wipes a tear) He sure did.
You must be - let’s see - you about three months gone?
Almost.
What you cryin’ about? Sharon pulling Tish fully in, the curiosity over, all mothering now.

Now listen, you got enough on your mind without worrying about being a bad girl and all that jive-ass shit. I sure hope I raised you better than that. If you was a bad girl you wouldn't be sitting on this bed, you’d long been turning tricks for the warden. Tish picking her head up, wiping more tears, getting hers back together:
Now you and Fonny be together right now, married or not, wasn't for that damn white man. So, let me tell you what you got to do.

You got to hold on to that baby, don't care what else happens or don't happen. You got to do that. Can't nobody else do that for you. And we going to get Fonny out. And that baby be the best thing that ever happened to him. It’s going to give him a whole lot of courage. (beat) Am I getting through to you?
Yes, Mama.
Now, when your Daddy and Ernestine get home, we going to sit at the table together, and I'll make the family announcement. I think that might be easier, don't you?
Yes. Sharon rises from the bed.
Take off them streets clothes and lie down for a minute. I'll come get you. Sharon opens the door.
Mama?
Yes, Tish?
Thank you.

(laughing) I don’t know what you thanking me for. I’m your mama, ain’t I? Sharon closing the door behind her, leaves Tish in here alone. Tish taking off her coat and shoes, slowly, all th tiredness overtaking her again. As she gets her shoes to floor... ..+.the doorbell rings. Here. Drink this. Do you good. Sharon carrying a small saucer, has a small water glass a shot glass beside. Sharon taking the brown liquid of the glass, pours it into the water. And then she’s gone again, out that door, heels clicking along the hall that leads to the front door. From the sou of the banter, a man entering, in a good mood:
Forgot my keys, Tish home yet?
She's taking a little nap inside.

She going to see him Monday. Sound of feet moving throughout the house now, of the fri door opening and closing. Tish downing her water and bran

Joe, you know damn well ain't no point in asking me that question.

Amen to that.  Tish lying back on the bed, looking up and into those curtains. Somewhere out there, the sun setting. As she rubs her belly, let’s her thoughts wonder... CUT TO BLACK. “Fonny used to go to a vocational school where they teach kids to make all kinds of shitty things..."

See a “slightly” younger Fonny working at a table-saw, a piece of timber split down the trunk atop his work statio “,..like card tables and hassocks and chests of drawers w nobody's ever going to buy.”

INT. TISH’S HOME, LIVING ROOM - NIGHT A woman we've not seen before entering the apartment now, slender, taller, a few years older than Tish but still yo This is Tish’s sister, ERNESTINE.

Where's Tish? Sharon and JOSEPH (a little older than Sharon, a large, y subtle presence) over near the kitchen, Joe nursing a bee looking in on his wife preparing supper. Both their faces opening at the sight of Ernestine.
She's home. She's lying down. Ernestine setting her purse down, continuing over to...

Taking it.

Daddy, we paid him his retainer, that's why ain't none of us got no clothes. And I know we got to pay expenses, but he ain't supposed to get no more money until he brings Fonny to trial.
He says it's a tough case.
Shit. What's a lawyer for?  11.
To make money.
You got that right.

They don't want to know nothing about it, you know that. Mrs. Hunt and them two camellias is just in disgrace. And poor Frank ain't got no money.
Well. Let's not talk too much about it in front of Tish. We'll work it out somehow.
Shit. We got to work it out. Fonny's like one of us.
He is one of us. All heads turning here at a bit of light out in the livin room, the sound of footsteps approaching. A moment later Tish appears, hair mottled and cajoled, just woke up:
Well hello there, baby sister. A kiss on the cheek and a hug between Tish and Ernestine: these too clearly love each other.

Well alright then, if y’all want to eat, better get your behinds out of my kitchen, this food ain’t gon’ fix itself. Come on now, take your business into the living room.  12. This... is a sacrament. And no, I ain’t gone crazy. We’re drinking to a new life. (beat) Tish is gonna have Fonny’s baby. The air heavy in here for a beat, no one moving. Sharon reaches a hand to Joe’s shoulder.

(softly) Drink. Joe staring at Tish, frozen in the moment of that news. Tish staring back, holding his gaze, only openness. Joe puts his glass down. Then he picks it up again. That's a hell of a note. Joe takes a sip of his brandy, a good, deep swallow:
Ain't you going to drink to the little one, Tish?  14. Tish nodding, takes the lightest sip of that brandy, stil rouses a cough in her, Ernestine patting her on the back.
How long this been going on?
About three months.
Yeah. That's what I figured.
Three months! ?
Since March.

While you two was running around looking at places? Joe asking this question as much to himself as to anyone else. The women understanding, allowing that question the proper space to drift out, refract. After a moment, after a few more long sips:
You sure you want this baby?

Oh, yes, and Fonny wants it, too. It's our baby, don't you see? And it's not his fault that he’s in jail, it’s not like he ran away. (pleading) And we've always been best friends, ever since we were little, you know that. And we'd be married now, if-if--
Your father know that. He's only worried about you.
Don't you go thinking I think you a bad girl, or any foolishness like that. I just asked you that because you so young, that's all, and--  15.
(raising her glass) Un-bow your head sister.
To the newborn.
I hope it’s a boy, that’d tickle old Frank to pieces, I bet. (a thought grabbing him) Tish, do you mind... if I break the news to him?
No daddy, I don’t mind.
(with attitude) I sure would like to be the one to tell them sisters.

Joe, why don't you just call up and ask them all over here? Hell, it's Saturday night and it ain't late and we still got a lot of brandy in the bottle. And now that I think about it, it's really the best way to do it. Joe looking to his wife, had already started for his coat but... considering Sharon’s proposal:

You know you right love, let’s get them over here. Joe turning down that long hall adjoining the bedrooms. A his footfalls pad away, we stay here, with these women listening to Joe on the phone down that hall. Beat. Joe coming back down that hallway now, re-enters the livi room, takes a seat at the one recliner in here:
Mrs. Hunt... is getting dressed. (smiles at Tish) Come on over here, daughter. Tish rising from her spot on the couch, moves from mother father, sits beside Joe, head rested to his shoulder:  16.
You're a good girl, Tish. I’m proud of you. Don’t you forget that.
She ain't going to forget it. I’1ll whip her ass if she do.
But she’s pregnant! A big, way deep down laugh from all of them at this, Ernestine and Sharon both throwing their heads back. As the laughter subsides...
Shall we dress for Mrs. Hunt? Another laugh now, something in the room spreading.
Look. We got to be nice, okay?

Oh we'll be nice; Lord knows we'll be nice, you raised us right. It’s just you didn’t never buy us no clothes. But Mrs. Hunt and them sisters, they got wardrobes! Ain't no sense in trying to compete with them.
I didn’t run no tailor shop.

Well who’s fault is that? Ernestine rubbing her father’s head playfully as she move from the living room, Joe smiling at her touch. Head resting at Joe’s shoulder, eyes lingering across thi room, Tish appears to be somewhere else, lost in the drif “The very first time Fonny and I made love was strange.” EXT. DETAILS of him making his way along this walk, as strong we've seen him, dressed in a red and black lumberjack coa grey corduroy slacks and heavy shoes.

The light falling, getting on to dusk.  18. Fonny and Tish moving, slowly tracing the paths of this p passing the wayfarers so integral to the charm of this pl Somehow, the two not touching here: Tish’s arms folded ab herself, Fonny’s hands clasped behind his back.
I've slept in this park sometimes. (off her look) No, it’s not a good idea. Fonny reaching into his coat pocket now, retrieving a cigarette. Gestures to Tish:
Not right now, thank you. (and innocently) Why did you sleep in the park? Fonny taking a quick beat to get his cigarette lit:
It was late. Didn’t want to go home. Didn't want to wake up none of you neither. Check’s Tish’s response: clearly she’s never assumed some she loves has had to sleep in this park.
But I got me a pad down here now. I'll show it to you, you want to see it?
(after a nod) I'd like that. These two still walking, circling a path around the park. Fonny reaches an arm out, pulls her in close:
You all right?
Yeah.
Good. (and) You want to eat down here or you want to wait till we get back uptown?  19.

Or you want to go to the movies or you want a little wine or you want a little pot or a beer or a cup of coffee? (and, a smile) Or you just want to walk a little more before you make up your mind? Fonny’s grinning now, warm and sweet, brings his arm back from around her and takes her hand in his, swinging it li little boy; a happy little boy. END MONTAGE. INT. Yes. He’s fine. He sends his love.  20.
They ain’t giving him too hard a time, is they? I ask you like that because, you know, he might say things to you he won’t say to me.

Lovers’ secrets. Tish’s eyes cutting to the source of that voice: ADRIENNE the older of the two Hunt sisters (with SHEILA being the other), sitting on the couch now, crossing her legs and folding those arms with a shit-eating smirk.
Well. He hates it, you can see that. And he should. But he’s strong. He’ll be alright... but we've got to get him out of there.

What you know about it you-- You bring that six-pack man?
Or I got some gin and we got whiskey and we got some brandy. Ain’t got no Thunderbird though-- (and, to Mrs. Hunt) I’m sure you ladies won’t mind?
Mind? Frank does not care if we mind.
Mrs. Hunt, what can I get you, sugar? I can offer you some tea, or coffee; and we got ice cream, and Coca Cola.

Yeah Mrs. Hunt, I can make you an ice-cream soda. Come on Sheila, you want to help me? (grabbing Sheila) Sit down Mama, me and Sheila got it.  21. Sharon taking Sheila’s place now, Mrs. Hunt having sat be her daughters on the couch there:
Lord, the time sure flies. We ain’t hardly seen each other since this trouble started.

Don't say a word. I have been running myself sick, all up and down the Bronx, trying to get the very best legal advice I can find. I just pray and pray and pray that the Lord will bring my boy to the light. That's all I pray for, every day and every night. A long pause from Mrs. Hunt here, moment of reflection:
And then, sometimes I think that maybe this is the Lord's way of making my boy think on his sins and surrender his soul to Jesus.
You might be right. The Lord sure works in mysterious ways.
Oh yes. Now he may try you. But he ain’t never left none of His children alone.
What you think of the lawyer Ernestine found, Mr. Hayward?
I haven't seen him yet. (defensive) I just have not had time to get downtown. But I know Frank saw him--
What you think Frank?
(shrugs ) It’s a white boy who’s been to law school and he got them degrees. I ain’t got to tell you what that means: it don’t mean shit.  22.
You're talking to a woman.

I'm hip, and it’s a mighty welcome change. (pause) Like I was saying, it don’t mean shit and I ain’t sure we’re going to stay with him. On the other hand, as white boys go, he’s not so bad: he’s young and hungry, so he’s not as full of shit now as he may be when he’s full.

But I keep trying to tell you, that it's that negative attitude, you're so full of hate! If you give people hatred, they will give it back to you! Every time I hear you talk this way my heart breaks for my son, sitting in a dungeon which only the love of God can bring him out of.
He's not talking hatred, Maybeline. He's just telling the truth.
I trust in God, I know He cares for me.

I don't know how God expects a man to act when his son is in a cage. Your God crucified His son and was probably glad to get rid of him, but I ain't like that. I ain't hardly going out in the street and kiss the first white cop I see. But I'll be a very loving motherfucker the day my son walks out of that hellhole, free. Oh, I'll be full of love, that day. Mrs. Hunt puts her head in her hands as Frank slowly cros the room again, sits near Joe at the dining table.
Mr. Rivers, exactly what is the purpose of this meeting?  23.
You haven't called us all the way over here just to watch my father insult my mother?
Why not? It's Saturday night. You can't tell what people won't do if they get bored enough. Maybe we just invited you over to liven things up?
I can believe that you're that malicious... but I can't believe you're that stupid. Off Tish, CUT TO...

Okay, Fonny. (and again) Okay. INT. TISH’S HOME, LIVING ROOM - NIGHT - RESUMING Ernestine and Sheila returning from the kitchen carrying platters of drinks; the smile on Ernestine’s face is pure delight, the one on Sheila’s? Not so much. Ernestine setting down her tray, raising her glass:
Happy landings. Everyone going quiet now. Everyone... waiting and, in the space of this waiting, everyone's eyes slowly, definitive drawing themselves to...

All eyes on Tish, for once alone in the room, neither her parents nor Ernestine beside her. Tish rises, nervous hand running down her waist to smooth dress. She takes a step, just a small one, symbolic, towa Frank:

I called this meeting. I had Daddy ask you all to come over so I could tell you what I had to tell Fonny this afternoon. Mrs. Hunt setting down her ice-cream float. Sharon taking sip of her gin and tonic. Ernestine... smiling.

All at once in this room, several things: Mrs. Hunt’s eye leaving Tish, lowering, eyes to the floor;  26. Frank and Joe turning to one another, holding each other' gaze in silence; Sheila and Adrienne rolling their eyes i contempt; Sharon and Ernestine making eye contact, a wink sip.
(to Joe) You and me? We going to go out and get drunk. A huge laugh of joy from Frank, the clasping of hands bet these two.
(at Tish) I’m glad. Don’t you worry, I’m mighty--

The father and the mother. Mrs. Hunt staring, something smoldering in her.
You can bet that it won’t be the Holy damn Ghost. Mrs. Hunt shooting Frank a look of disgust, then rising, begins slowly crossing the room:

I guess you call your lustful action love. I don’t. I always knew you'd be the destruction of my son. The Bible says: “Put to death therefore what is earthly in you: sexual immorality, impurity, passion, evil desire and covetousness.” (and) That child is borne of sin, the Holy Ghost will cause it to shrivel in your womb. But my son will be forgiven. My prayers will--
From nowhere and everywhere, Frank here standing over Mrs Hunt having knocked her senseless, sprawled to the floor.  27.
Her heart!
I think you’ll find it’s still pumping. But I wouldn’t call it no heart. Frank does not look remorseful, more sad than anything, s over everything.
Joe, let the women take care of her and come on with me. Joe hesitating, still shocked by the violence:
Please man, come on.
Go on with him, Joe. Go on. Ernestine moving past Sharon, has a bottle of rubbing alc and a hand full of cotton balls.

Go on. We don’t need you here. Joe nodding at his wife in ascent, eyes on Mrs. Hunt as h rounds the living room, takes his coat from a chair-back, hand to Frank’s shoulder just ahead of him.
